” Gwendolyn Ifill was born in Queens, N Y on Sept. 29, 1955, and grew up as the fifth of six siblings.
She was born in New York City to a Panamanian immigrant father and a Barbadian mother.
” She grew up in New York City and graduated from Simmons College in Boston, according to her PBS bio.
She was a journalist’s journalist and set an example for all around her.
She called Ifill ”a journalist’s journalist” who combined warmth and authority so well that people on the street who had seen her on television would hug her.

Because of her father’s low pay, she noted at one time that she was likely the only Washington journalist covering the Department of Housing and Urban Development who had also lived federally subsidized housing.

Trailblazing journalist and New York native Gwen Ifill,   of PBS’ “NewsHour,” died of cancer on Monday.
PBS reporter Gwen Ifill  —   who died November 14 at 61 years old  —   was and remains greatly respected throughout the field of journalism.

Gwen Ifill, who covered politics for some of the country’s premier newspapers before transitioning to broadcast journalism and making her greatest mark as one of the most prominent TV anchors of her generation, died Nov. 14 at a hospice center in Washington.
Gwen Ifill, one of the most prominent political journalists in the country, has died, according to PBS She was 61.
Ifill said she was keenly aware of her role as one of the few   women with a   job in TV news.

Later, as her career took her from The Washington Post and New York Times to NBC News and PBS, she reflected ruefully on her family’s struggle: “I make more money in a week than my father made in a year.
She went on to write for the Washington Post and the New York Times.
In an interview with The New York Times, she reflected on what her appointment could mean to a new generation.
Ifill joined the programs in 1999 from NBC News, where she was chief congressional and political correspondent, according to a biography on the ”NewsHour” website.
When she took the helm of Washington Week in Review in 1999, Ifill became the first   woman to host a major political TV talk show.
But with her appointment in 1999 to lead what was then called “Washington Week in Review,” she became one of the first African American women to preside over a major national political show.

From beginning her career in the early 1980s as a reporter at the Baltimore Evening Sun, to covering seven separate presidential campaigns, to becoming the   of PBS NewsHour in 2013, Ifill contributed over three decades of judicious, empathetic, and incisive work in media.
Ifill was the   author of 2009’s ”The Breakthrough: Politics and Race in the Age of Obama” and moderated the vice presidential debates during the 2004 and 2008 national elections.
Ifill covered seven presidential campaigns and moderated the vice presidential debates in 2004 and 2008.
She started her journalism career as a print reporter for the Baltimore Evening Sun and the Boston Herald American.

”  She began her reporting career in the late 1970s, with stints at newspapers in Boston and Baltimore, assertively carving a niche for herself as a political journalist at a time when black journalists and black female reporters, in particular, were rare in newsrooms and rarer still on the city hall beat.
” Before going in front of the camera, Ifill started her career in newspapers  —   first at the Baltimore Evening Sun and then the Boston Herald American.
She also had been White House correspondent for the New York Times and a reporter for the Washington Post, Baltimore Evening Sun and the Boston Herald American.

After PBS announced in 2013 that she and Judy Woodruff would be the first two woman to   NewsHour together, Ifill told the New York Times why being this visible on broadcast television was so important to her:     When I was a little girl watching programs like this  —   because that’s the kind of nerdy family we were  —   I would look up and not see anyone who looked like me in any way.

At a peak moment of Ms Ifill’s broadcasting power, soon after becoming   of “The NewsHour,” she told the Times, “When I was a little girl watching programs like this    because that’s the kind of nerdy family we were    I would look up and not see anyone who looked like me in any way.
On the ”NewsHour website, Ifill said that ”public broadcasting provides the best of both worlds   combining the depth of newspapering with the immediate impact of broadcast television”.
Not having Ifill in the NewsHour seat anymore is a huge blow to representation for women, and specifically black woman, in news media.
